title: How many UN member states will sign the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons before 1 November 2017?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Today is 10/30 and only have 53 countries signed the treaty. with 1 day left, it's highly unlikely the number will go over 100.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/ Still only 53 signatories, none after 22 September. 47 more in the next 16 days is asking for too much.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Only 15 days for many more countries to sign.
53 countries signed right away, so the treaty will take effect, no reason for more to sign.

Still only 53 members on Oct 7, there isn't much time before Nov 1.
http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/

As of 10/06 there are only 53 signatories which is the same number as on the first day open for signatories, 9/20. I thought there might be some new signatories based on publicity of ICAN winning the Nobel Peace Prize.
Going with the consensus; of note, news, analysis by @Khalid at  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/589494

http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/ Still only 53 signatories according to the ICANW (international Campaign to abolish nuclear weapons) website, which one would expect to be tracking the status closely. Reducing further to match consensus.

Based on passage of earlier non-proliferation treaty & other weapon treaties, seems that most of the 192 members will sign.  Nuclear powers & those allied with them will not, but that's only about a dozen members.
Well this pace has slowed way down since the inicial burst, at this rate I'd be surprised if 60 countries sign the treaty by November.

uh, this went far worse than exptected. I followed the assessment of others which I believed to be right and thought myself that 100+ would be rather easy to get. I was clearly wrong. sorry. I do think its amazing though how this gets approved but then not signed in the end. Maybe NATO pressure made a difference, maybe it's something else. Maybe many states just did not feel the need to, as 50 suffices for the treaty to enter into force. But then, again, NATO already declared that this treaty will not be regarded as anything close to customary law & that it will affect nothing.
There is little time left till Nov 1, with only 53 signatures.

There are already 53 signatories, albeit none from Europe, the Middle East, N America (except Mexico), or Central Asia.  There were 123 votes for this treaty in 2016.  So I would not hold my breath for >140, and a month seems like a short time for much more ratification - OK, it's only been open since Sept 20, but at least some of the signatories has a document ready to go since July 7.  
https://www.un.org/disarmament/ptnw/
http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/ Still only 53 nations listed as having signed to date.
Following data and analyses provided by @Raahul_Kumar and @algernon, thank you both.

53 have already signed, making the lowest bucket impossible. US + allies + Nuclear weapon states won't sign, that makes 140 very difficult to reach.
http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/

Only 53 signatories as of October 1. It is very possible that the treaty will ultimately get over 100 signatories, but unlikely that this will happen by the end of this month. The initial rush is over.
Shifting a bit toward 50-100 because now that the initial burst of signatures is over I think we see the slow movement common to international treaties.

53 have signed.  It only needed 50 to pass it into law.  The rest of the signings will be for the purpose of making a "statement".  I am unaware of any reason why any country would feel the need to hurry signing this now that it has already become law.
As of September 25, it appears only 53 nations have signed. Looking at prior treaties, I would expect only a trickle of signatures to come in through the remainder of the forecast period.
world is nervous - this should increase # of signee countries in the near term
122 States voted for the Treaty, of which 53 have signed it.  The remaining countries will likely have to surmount high bureaucratic hurdles to sign Treaty by 1 Nov.
Following @Khalid's excellent data and analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/580223

The ongoing childish name-calling spat between Trump and Kim Jong Un, both armed with nuclear weapons, may give impetus to this treaty; this, despite all the current possessors of such weapons opposing this treaty. Dateline 9-20-2017 Nuclear weapons were the focus as global leaders addressed the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday, a day after President Trump vowed to “totally destroy” North Korea if it threatened the United States or its allies. Leaders from around the globe began adding their signatures to a treaty that bans nuclear weapons, although the world’s nine nuclear-armed countries declined to sign it and denounced it as dangerously naïve. President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, responding to Mr. Trump’s denunciation of the Iran nuclear deal as “an embarrassment,” defended the agreement in his own remarks to the General Assembly on Wednesday. Mr. Rouhani said the agreement could be “a new model for global interactions.” --https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/world/united-nations-general-assembly.html

My initial thought was that all 122 nations who voted for this treaty would sign, but within the first three days, when practically all had high level presence at the UN, only 53 had signed by 22 September. There are still 8 weeks left, so there's a good chance more than 100 will have signed by then, but all 122 is beginning to look optimistic.

It's legal with 51 on Sept. 20.  The next 50 will be more difficult (with less impact):
http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/51-countries-to-sign-un-treaty-outlawing-nuclear-weapons/article/502917

The treaty banning nuclear weapons opened yesterday for signatures at UN ceremony chaired by UN High Representative for Disarmament Affairs Izumi Nakamitsu, 42 countries signed the Treaty, with more expected later in the day. The Holy See and Thailand not only signed but also ratified it. 
Retrieved from:	http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57588#.WcP2p8iGNPY 50 have signed and 3 have ratified according to ICAN
Retrieved from:	http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/
Well I'm impressed, fifty have already signed it. Guess I need to shift up a bit.
50 countries signed so far, 3 already ratified. http://www.icanw.org/status-of-the-treaty-on-the-prohibition-of-nuclear-weapons/
Updating my forecast to reflect early reports on the number of signatories so far.

NATO calls upon all nations to reject this treaty. Dateline 9-20-2017 The fundamental purpose of NATO's nuclear capability is to preserve peace, prevent coercion, and deter aggression. Allies’ goal is to bolster deterrence as a core element of our collective defence and to contribute to the indivisible security of the Alliance. As long as nuclear weapons exist, NATO will remain a nuclear alliance. We call on our partners and all countries who are considering supporting this treaty to seriously reflect on its implications for international peace and security, including on the NPT. As Allies committed to advancing security through deterrence, defence, disarmament, non-proliferation and arms control, we, the Allied nations, cannot support this treaty. Therefore, there will be no change in the legal obligations on our countries with respect to nuclear weapons. Thus we would not accept any argument that this treaty reflects or in any way contributes to the development of customary international law.    http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_146954.htm
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Signing this treaty is more or less giving a F word to : the US, China, India, Russia, the UK, France, Israel and Pakistan. To all of them, at the same time.

A 2/3 majority of member states are required to ratify the treaty - ban on nuclear weapons before the Treaty takes effect.  193 of 195 are member states.  The Treaty is future oriented and I suspect that ratification will not be rushed by member states.  Significant differences among member states who support the ban exist.  Issues of verification and other matter simply will not be completed by 2017.  The last session meeting on this resolution occurred June/July 2017.

Backing out the nuclear states, NATO members and Japan and South Korean leaves about 157 members that might vote for the Treaty. However, of the 157 non-nuclear members only 135 were involved with the conference negotiating the treaty and only 122 members voted it out of conference. Using pass Treaties involving nuclear issues as a base, roughly 90% of the members actually become signatories. So, 122 less 10% leaves roughly 109 members that would sign. Taking into account the members that ICAN labelled as "Unclear" how they might vote on this issue, does not move the needle. What might change my mind is just how active the anti-nuclear weapons civil society groups become around this vote.
Highly beneficial for a large majority of the voting body. The only states this truly hurts are the large powers which are limited in number and boycotted the talks.
Bureaucracy of UN moves slowly, no time limits so limited numbers are more likely on this short term.

Certainly some number of the 122 UN member states who voted in July to adopt it at the negotiating conference will sign it at this year's UNGA.   The P5 and NATO will no doubt launch an intensive diplomatic campaign against signature, but many or most of the pro-disarmament Non-Aligned Movement members will sign as a symbolic gesture.

The debate in Canada: Nuclear powers boycott of treaty vs 2019 Security Council seat may depend on support for the treaty.
http://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/canada-faces-political-risk-at-united-nations-over-treaty-to-ban-nuclear-weapons
122 nations voted for it, so that is the most likely number to sign it, but a few will be slow, so 100-122 is most likely range.

South American and African nations are pushing this.  Meaning, NATO and American allies, Russia and their allies, China and their allies all abstain.  My only concern is that others sign to "look peaceful" with no intention of complying, backed by their favorite super power.  Is my cynicism getting the better of my judgement???

No neutral country is signing, no European country, no country with nuclear arms. The treaty would not describe how to control, in the contrary could weaken existing treates. There is no momentum building up.

The vote on the UN Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons was left abandoned by all nuclear capable countries and many of their allies.  The total number of yes votes was 122.  The date to sign the bill into international law is on September 20th of this year.  The wildcards are the Netherlands, who voted no, and Singapore which abstained.  I chuckled seeing the Netherlands no vote.    Another waste of paper and time by the UN.

US Secretary of Defence James Mattis sent a letter to Swedish Defence Minister Peter Hultqvist warning the Nordic nation of a negative impact on relations should they sign an anti-nuclear bomb treaty, according to a report in a Swedish newspaper.
Svenska Dagbladet (SvD) reports that the letter was registered at the Swedish Department of Defence on Tuesday, and regards Sweden's intention to sign a treaty banning nuclear bombs when it opens for signatures from any UN member state in September.
https://www.thelocal.se/20170830/us-defence-secretary-mattis-warned-sweden-not-to-sign-anti-nuclear-weapons-treaty-report

The treaty does not open for signatures until September 20.  Only 120 countries voted to adopt this treaty and none of the nuclear nations support it.  Legislative bodies and governments  generally take months to a few years to approve treaties and there is no reason to expect this one to be any different even if it is just a political statement.

African and South American states will be able to sign quickly adding up to less than 100 states. NATO member states will not sign and other countries in Asia etc. With nuclear weapons will be reluctant. The USA under Trump won't sign, anyway.

I am revising my forecast based on looking at the Ottowa (landmine) treaty as a model. In the case of the Ottowa treaty, 82 nations signed it on the first day, 38 on the second day, and 2 more followed within the 40-day period afterwards. Unlike the Ottowa treaty, the TPNW would probably have a significant effect on nuclear deterrence strategy, because it could put constraints on which third-party states could host nuclear arsenals. However, I think the states that possess nuclear weapons have already put targeted pressure on the nations they believe to be strategically important for nuclear deterrence (or war), and those states have stayed out of the negotiating process, and are unlikely to sign. Of the 122 states that took part in the negotiating process, I think only a few of those will continue to come under pressure from the nuclear powers. Looking at the performance of those 122 around the Ottowa treaty, I think about 50-60 will sign on the first day the treaty is open for signature, and 20-30 more will sign in the days before November 1.

Looking at a less controversial subject (Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities), only 91 of the nations that voted on CRPD actually signed it within 40 days of it becoming available for signature. Taking these 91 nations to be a group that is likely to sign a treaty quickly after voting on it, 56 of them also voted for the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons, so I take that to be the maximum number that would sign the treaty before November 1. 56 is a difficult number because of the way the possible answers are broken out (< 50, 50-100, etc). Since this is a controversial treaty, and I expect the nuclear nations to lobby their allies to not sign it, I expect a lower number than 56, but I am not sure how low that number will be. My 50/50 forecast represents my uncertainty on how effective this lobbying will be.

The treaty, while toothless, is a good opportunity for nations to signal virtue. I would place high confidence (>80%) of signing by all non-nuclear weapon states that are not protected by the United States' extended deterrence. Countries protected by extended deterrence are unlikely to sign (>70%), and I judge there to be a >90% chance that no nuclear weapon possessing state will sign it.
Forecast based on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/556487, but I'm more pessimistic that the full number will sign it before the specified date.
Following @JS on the basis of his report here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/556487

I've just realised I've been misreading the options. I consider 122 to be a likely number, but I've been assigning a very low probability to the option in which it actually falls. I'm now straddling 101-121 and 122-140.
Correcting forecast error, having entered 20/70/10 earlier.

Adjusting after very helpful post below from @JS
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/556494 My feeling is that all 122 who voted for the resolution in the General Assembly can be expected to sign the Treaty eventually, very probably within the six weeks period of this question (even though some may come under renewed pressure from the big powers not to do so). However, I'm more skeptical about any additional countries signing - though the fact that 135 countries took part in the earlier negotiations indicates it is certainly possible, especially once the first 50 countries have signed, thus bringing it into force.
EDIT - I've corrected my forecast to 80% for the 101-121 option, with 10% allocated to each of the adjacent options.

@cmeinel @Rene @Khalid @Dsarin  I asked around and made a major change to my forecast by raising the "between 122 and 140" forecast and  dropping "between 50 and 100". According to people I asked, it is probable that all or almost all 122 states will indeed sign the treaty. The vote of those present was very clear after all: 122 votes in favor, one vote against and one abstience. There are no signs that they wouldn't sign the treaty and I currently don't know of any state in wich this treaty might require ratification first (happy about further input on this!). Overall 135 states participated in the negotiations. ICAN provides an overview of current positions here: http://www.icanw.org/why-a-ban/positions/. 60 states are either against the treaty or their position is not known yet. It cannot be ruled out, that at least some of them will sign. In fact, it can be expected that at least some of them will indeed do so, as it might be better to have this treaty than no treaty at all. My only reason keeping 50% in the middle box is the timerame and the high consensus here that so far contradicts my assessment and those of the people I asked.  As always, there are no guarantess though. Don't punch me if less than 100 sign the treaty in time. ;)
The usual bifurcations within the group.

Interesting way to get to this goal - go around the inside players at the UN. The difference between nuclear vs landmines is deterrence depends on the 'nuclear' complete annihilation ramifications. it's ironic that the world thinks we need the nuclear option and that landmines just kill and maimed innocent civilians. Voting to adopt and actually signing the treaty are two different things. I have doubts even the 122 countries that voted to adopt the measure will end up signing it as all the NATO and Security council members can and will put pressure to bear on any allies, and this is a low-risk carrot-and-stick option for countries to wield their influence - once signed that pull-push option is gone. The other element is whether or not signing will have any bearing on anything else in the international political realm - likely no.

Forecasting on the shoulders of giants (@cmeinel and @Raisinville). I don't have any research into this question so I did a very fast math equation for a base rate based on @Raisinville 's insight into the non-probability of the extremes:
100/122=82%
22/122=22% Lowering the % significantly due to @cmeinel 's forecast stating she is following someone who actually has insight and my admittedly poor basis for a base rate calculation. My energy in forecasting on this one will grow exponentially once the 'horse race' starts.

Following JS because I know who he is in real life and he's qualified to answer this question. On the other hand, I could be wrong as even the best forecasters make big mistakes sometimes. Also I'm taking @Khalid's advice to check back often beginning on Sept. 20, 2017, when the treaty is open for signature. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/553089
Since 122 countries were involved in the adoption then it is almost certain that at least 50 will sign. More than 100 may depend on how much pressure the nuclear countries can put on allies.

The 2013 Arms Trade Treaty got a 154 to 3 vote in the General Assembly with 23 abstentions and some other countries not participating in the vote. Formal signature was open on June 3, 2013. As of now, there are 133 signatories (including 41 that have not ratified), or 86% of the yes votes. About 60% of these countries signed in June or July 2013. Most of these signatures were in the first week. The vote on the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons was 122-1 with 1 abstention and 69 countries not voting (including every country with nuclear weapons). Signatures are open September 20. It would be very surprising if this treaty was signed faster than the Arms Trade Treaty, which had more support from the countries whose compliance it needs to be effective. (5 of the world's top ten arms producers ratified the treaty. The U.S. signed but hasn't ratified.)  I think the most likely outcome is 50-80 signatures by November 1. 30-50 signatures is also quite possible. More than 100 would be moderately surprising. I would be very surprised if countries that did not vote yes become early signatories.

In July, 122 nations voted in favor of negotiations of the prohibition of Nuclear weapons.  Many countries did not participate in the vote.  I am anticipating that some of the non-participating countries would actually sign a treaty that is appropriately worded but I need to recognise that at this stage only 122 countries are saying that they will
Nice thing to do during the annual  meeting.   Halo points for signers whether they never can or never plan to develop such weapons and even if they do in the future.

There is short turn around between adoption and opening date for signature (Sept 20) but the timing puts a lot of high level diplomats at the UN in NYC in late September. Not all who adopted will sign, as they already expressed qualms ahead of adoption, but past treaties like the CCM in 08 had an ~87% rate of signature when it was opened up

I think there is a burst of signatures right at the start among countries in nuclear free zones but then it probably slows down as I think most countries have more important things to deal with. They will eventually get around to this.

There will be a flurry of African and South American states to sign, but I have it at 65/35 for getting to 100. Getting more than the 122 yea votes to sign within the first 41 days of the treaty being active seems far-fetched.
@Raisinville ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/552852 )  Needs frequent follow up during the weeks after this treaty opens for signature

The Treaty was adopted with  the vote of 122 members. The treaty will come in force 90 days after it is signed by 50 countries (may require ratification within each individual country?).  Like the CNTB Treaty, some countries may sign, but not ratify (like the US). In 1996 the CNBT (@The_Gnome) opened for signing on Sept. 24th.  71 countries signed on the first day, 98 signed by the end of September and 126 had signed before Nov. 1.  This time the numbers will likely be lower, given group of  countries (like NATO) have defensive agreements partially based on nuclear capabilities. - Setting the top limit at 122, as it seems unlikely that a country that abstained or voted no at the UN would be able to sign the Treaty before November.  Eliminating the 140+ option. - 122 seems unlikely as all 122 that voted for the Treaty, would sign before November.  Giving a very low probability to the 122 - 140 bucket. 50 seems like a good number.  Given the need for 50 signatories for the Treaty to go into effect; advocates would be motivated to sign-up soon as possible, perhaps even aiming for the start of the signing period on 20 Sept. 2017. Less than 50 seems unlikely.

@Intriligator: This is the first international treaty, coordinated by UN members that will be legally binding if ratification occurs.   For the draft agreement, 122 nation states were in favor, 1 voted against, 1 abstention, while 69 nations did not vote.  While the treaty will be open for signature in the near future, the duration of is period is indefinite.   Once there is a clearer specification of the closed duration on the signatures, nation states must then ratify the treaty, effective for implementation 2020 . While the intent of the 122 potential signatories have agreed to the draft treaty, it is not clear when and how these nation states will proceed with their legislative bodies and interactions among its executives branches in respective nation states.  What is clear that the stated objective will be accomplished after the deadline for the IFP. Estimate changed in follow up forecast.

122 have signed the draft - no NATO countries and no nuclear weapon countries. Some nations might not sign if big nations are not signing, or will wait. UN resolution does not state a clear date when it shall be signed.
